description.narrative: Formative research and development of Behavior Change Communication materials for Care Groups. Training Health Promoters and Care Group Volunteers. Village initiation sessions. Care Group visits to neighbor women. Nutrition baseline - Research and promote indigenous foods rich in Vitamin A. Provision of vitamin A supplements and deworming tablets at community level through various forums. Sessions on infant feeding conducted with pregnant and breast feeding women. Exchange visits for experiential learning. Dissemination of information on importance of mosquito nets.

The Reducing Chronic Malnutrition in Somaliland (RECMAS) project targets nomadic/semi-nomadic, agro-pastoral drop-outs and internally displaced persons (IDPs) aimed at reducing malnutrition among high-risk groups (young children and lactating and pregnant women), through promotion of the care group model in nine villages.
RECMAS will aim at increasing appreciation and understanding amongst women and men of best maternal and child nutrition practices that supports prevention of malnutrition. All community members will benefit from activities through adoption of key behaviors, including personal hygiene, proper nutrition, food preparation, and community child care. Households, communities, districts and the nation will benefit since healthier and more well-nourished children translate into smarter and healthier youth and adults that can contribute to the workforce.
